Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Economic Downturns, Global Pandemics and Parliamentary Elections

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Under what conditions do voters withdraw or withhold their support from governments and how do economic and pandemic stressors affect popular support for governments and political leaders? This project advances understanding of how electoral rules, electoral integrity, perceptions of regime popularity and longevity, and the nature of electoral alternatives shape government support. Using surveys timed to Russia’s 2021 parliamentary election and including questions from the Comparative Study of Electoral Systems, this project extends the longest running election study in an autocratic setting and the only covering an extended period of retreat from democracy. The data from this project are an important resource for scholars of authoritarianism, comparative electoral behavior, and political parties, and its findings are also relevant to journalists, policymakers and the public.

Existing scholarship gives good reason to believe that declining popular support can undermine regimes around the world. However, the precise nature of these processes and the long-term developments that lead to regime change remain poorly understood. This study uses a nationally representative panel survey conducted before and after Russia’s 2021 State Duma election to advance knowledge on two of the most consequential forms of political behavior and politically salient metrics of a regime’s popular support: turnout and vote choice. The project’s theoretical contribution focuses on key differences in how voters process information about government performance and assess available political alternatives, with special attention to how polarization, preference falsification, and voters’ emotional states affect their interpretation of new information during crises.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project addressed foundational questions about mass support for autocracy: Under what conditions do voters withhold their support from autocratic regimes and how do regime stressors like a pandemic, protest, elections, and war affect support for authoritarian leaders? To answer these questions, we (1) developed new theory and (2) fielded a two-wave panel survey, among a nationally representative probability-based sample of Russian respondents, continuing the long-running Russian Election Studies (RES) series. Additionally, this project (3) contributed to the training and professionalization of graduate and undergraduate students, yielded policy-relevant analysis and media commentary, and generated new teaching resources.

Below we detail this project's contributions to political science research, the study of Russian politics, and public knowledge about Russia:

1.  The development of new theoretical frameworks that clarify the dynamics underlying defection cascades, regime support, and high-risk collective action, as well as change in citizens' information consumption patterns.

First, we contribute new theory to explain how informational cascades affect regime support. A central finding of our research is that negative information about an autocrat's popularity can rapidly precipitate sincere updating of regime preferences, and not only give citizens who already oppose the regime permission to openly state their opposition (Buckley et al. 2024, APSR). Second, we extend research on polarization. While polarized attitudes have been identified as key to voters' response to incumbents' illiberal behavior in backsliding democracies, we clarify that stoking antipathy toward political out-groups can also be an effective strategy for autocrats trying to prevent deconsolidation. Third, we clarify how emotions, particularly anger, help ordinary citizens overcome a baseline aversion to political risk-taking--even when the strong organizational ties emphasized by exiting literature on high-risk participation are absent. Fourth, we explain how heightened anxiety shapes citizens' information preferences, providing the first evidence in an autocracy for a specific emotional mechanism behind increased interest in information during crises.

An additional line of research on preference falsification and nonresponse in Russian surveys leverages the project's unique design to study panel attrition after the full-scale invasion of Ukraine and cross-validate multiple indirect measures of regime and war support.

2. The design and execution of an in-person panel survey, with pre- and post-election waves and complementary survey experiments, to test causal arguments and mechanisms.

The RES 2021-2023 panel survey interviewed approximately 4,000 Russian adults face-to-face, using probability-based sampling. In wave one (August-September 2021), a nationally representative sample of 2,700 respondents was collected. In wave two (November-December 2021), 1,700 of those respondents were reinterviewed. We also added a nationally representative refresh sample of 1,200 respondents. With probability weights, this yields a nationally representative post-election sample of nearly 3,000 respondents. This is, to our knowledge, the largest ever election panel survey conducted in Russia.

NSF support to establish this panel also made possible a 2023 follow-up survey. Together these three survey waves constitute, to our knowledge, the only probability-based face-to-face panel survey in Russia with interviews before and after the invasion of Ukraine. This individual-level evidence is uniquely well-suited to studying how and why the war has transformed a range of political attitudes.

The RES has covered every national election cycle in Russia for nearly three decades. As the longest running election study in an autocracy and the only covering an extended period of authoritarian consolidation, its continuation contributes an essential public good for scholars of Russia and Eastern Europe, authoritarianism, comparative electoral behavior, and political parties, as well as anyone who wants to understand public opinion and political attitudes in Russia. Data collected under this award will be publicly archived and available with previous RES surveys on the new RES website, along with the first guide to RES trend questions.

3. The training of graduate and undergraduate students through collaborative research and multi-level mentorship; dissemination of policy-relevant analysis via the media, briefings and analytical reports for government officials, and public events; and the creation of new educational resources.

This project provided skill-building and professionalization opportunities to 15 graduate and undergraduate students, including from historically underrepresented groups in political science, through regular meetings of an RES research group. Additionally, an open call for questions resulted in original data collection for three doctoral students/early-career scholars.

Key findings from this project informed public discourse on a country of vital national security interest. Our analysis appeared in The Washington Post and Foreign Affairs. It was shared with government officials in briefings and analytical reports and presented at a public event in Washington D.C.

Finally, data and findings from the project illustrate trends in party identification, the reasons why Russians vote, the correlates of Vladimir Putin's support, views on the Ukraine war, and attitudes toward government performance throughout the textbook Politics in Russia (8th ed.), under contract with Routledge, and in a new chapter "Putin and the Dynamics of Russia's Political System" in Developments in Russian Politics (10th ed.).
